Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics and geometry of large groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal concerns interactions between ergodic theory and the study of infinite groups. This includes the use of ergodic theoretic concepts, in particular a revised notion of group boundaries, for the study of superrigidity phenomena for various groups. In another direction, it is suggested to use group actions imbedding in certain classical dynamical systems to prove simplicity of the Lyapunov spectrum - an important quantitative characteristic of chaotic behavior of a system. Additional problems in "measured group theory" are proposed.

The proposed project will continue to explore many of the surprising connections between Algebra, Geometry and Dynamics. Part of the proposal describes ways in which some implicit symmetries of certain dynamical systems yield rigidity of groups. In the other direction, presence of groups with certain properties, is conjectured to yield certain dynamical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by the grant focused on certain connections between Dynamical Systems and symmetries. The field of Dynamical Systems, that emerged from Physics (problems in Celestial Mechanics and Statistical Mechanics) developed to a very active area of research in Mathematics that has strong ties to almost all branches of Mathematics: Algebra, Geometry, Analysis. Study of symmetries is one of the central topics in Algebra. 

The projects supported by the current proposal were concerned with the use of Dynamical Systems to study certain problems in Algebra, namely super-rigidity phenomena after Margulis and Zimmer. Very roughy speaking, the idea here is to use some small amount of unexpected symmetry and to use dynamics to show how this can cause a lot of rigidity and redundancy in the related large algebraic structures. 

Most of the proposed problems in this part of the grant were successfully carried out and resulted in a number of publications, were focus of a week long conference (Arbeitsgemeinschaft at Oberfolfach), and two additional lecture series at international conferences. Some of the techniques developed in this part of the grant suggest some further research, that we hope to pursue in the future.

Another project in the proposal suggested to use the ideas and the techniques used to draw these algebraic results (super-rigidity), and to use these techniques to study of dynamical systems themselves. This project turned out to be very successful: we managed to formulate quite flexible conditions on matrix valued functions over dynamical systems that ensure that these functions have behave very conveniently (have simple Lyapunov spectrum). This allows to give alternative simpler proofs to a number of important classical results on products of matrices, and to obtain many new results in this area.
